Oh!  thou most fatal of Pandora's train,</br>Consumption!  silent cheater of the eye;</br>Thou comest not robed in agonizing pain,</br>Nor mark'st thy course with Death's delusive dye,</br>But silent and unnoticed thou dost lie:</br>O'er life's soft springs thy venom dost diffuse,</br>And, while thou givest new lustre to the eye,</br>While o'er the cheek are spread health's ruddy hues,</br>E'en then life's little rest thy cruel power subdues.

Oft I've beheld thee in the glow of youth,</br>Hid 'neath the blushing roses which there bloomed;</br>And dropt a tear, for then thy cankering tooth</br>I knew would never stay, till, all consum'd,</br>In the cold vault of death he were entomb'd.

But oh!  what sorrow did I feel, as, swift,</br>Insidious ravager, I saw thee fly</br>Through fair Lucina's breast of whitest snow,</br>Preparing swift her passage to the sky.</br>Through still intelligence beamed in the glance,</br>The liquid lustre of her fine blue eye;</br>Yet soon did languid listlessness advance,</br>And soon she calmly sunk in death's repugnant trance.

Even when her end was swiftly drawing near,</br>And dissolution hovered o'er her head;</br>Even then so beauteous did her form appear,</br>That none who saw her but admiring said,</br>Sure so much beauty never could be dead.</br>Yet the dark lash of her expressive eye,</br>Bent lowly down upon the languid—</br>
